newsitem.title: USA: Teamsters chief says not optimistic in UPS talks.
newsitem.headline: Teamsters chief says not optimistic in UPS talks.

text.p: Teamsters President Ron Carey said he saw no reason for optimism ahead of a third round of contract talks with the United Parcel Service, scheduled to begin on Thursday.

"While there is no reason for optimism at this point, we will be there, ready to negotiate a reasonable agreement that provides the good jobs that American families need," Carey said in a statement after the talks were announced on Wednesday.

Earlier on Wednesday, Labor Secretary Alexis Herman said the two sides had agreed to resume talks to try to end the 10-day-old, nationwide strike of 184,000 Teamsters at the giant package delivery company.
Herman has been in almost round-the-clock contact with Teamster leaders and UPS managers since meeting separately with both parties on Monday.
UPS has called on U.S. President Bill Clinton to step in to end the strike, but White House spokesman Mike McCurry said Wednesday that Clinton continued to oppose intervention.
The Teamsters union has demanded better pay and the conversion of part-time jobs into full-time jobs, while UPS has said it will not improve its latest contract offer.
